IRS Code 841 Meaning

IRS Code 841 is the "refund cancelled" entry. Each 841 line shows that the IRS has cancelled a previously issued refund and credited the amount back to the account. This typically happens when a refund was returned as undeliverable or failed delivery. This page shows you how to recognize 841 in context, trace the failed refund path, identify what triggered the cancellation, and prepare clear client explanations about reissue options.

Try the parser (requires credits)

What Is IRS Code 841?

IRS Code 841 records the cancellation of a refund and the crediting of that amount back to the taxpayer's account. It is frequently paired with Code 740 (undeliverable refund returned) and prior Code 846 (refund issued).

When 841 posts, it means the IRS has formally cancelled a refund that was previously issued but not successfully delivered, and the funds have been credited back under IRS control.

When Does Code 841 Appear?

Common scenarios where you'll see Code 841 on a transcript include:

  1. After an undeliverable refund — A refund is issued (Code 846), returned (Code 740), and then cancelled and credited back via Code 841.
  2. When refund routing fails — Bank rejections, incorrect addresses, or other delivery failures lead to cancellation and re-crediting.
  3. As part of reissue workflows — 841 often appears before a manual refund (Code 840) or a new 846 issuance.

What Does Code 841 Usually Signal?

Professionally, Code 841 is the formal documentation that the original refund is no longer in-flight:

  • The funds have been credited back to the module and are under IRS control again.
  • Any reissue or offset will be reflected in subsequent transactions.
  • You need to explain to clients why a previously expected refund did not arrive.

What Should a Tax Professional Do Next?

  1. Reconstruct the path — Map the sequence from 846 (issued) to 740 (returned) to 841 (cancelled/credited) to show the full story.
  2. Check for reissue or manual refund — Look for Code 840 or a new Code 846 indicating funds were sent again.
  3. Clarify client expectations — Explain that the original refund was never successfully received and outline the next steps to secure a new payment.

Example: How This Looks in a Parsed Transcript Report

Refund cancelled example
Cancelled refund path
02/20/2024   Code 846, Refund Issued:                $2,300.00
03/10/2024   Code 740, Undeliverable Refund:        -$2,300.00
03/15/2024   Code 841, Refund Cancelled:             $2,300.00

Interpretation: The refund left the IRS, was returned, and then formally cancelled and credited back to the account. A reissue or manual refund decision is still pending.

Related IRS Transcript Codes

  • IRS Code 740 Meaning – Undeliverable Refund Returned.
  • IRS Code 840 Meaning – Manual Refund.
  • IRS Code 846 Meaning – Refund Issued.

FAQ: IRS Code 841

What does IRS Code 841 mean on a transcript?

Code 841 means a refund was cancelled and the amount was credited back to the tax module.

Does 841 mean the bank rejected the deposit or the check was returned?

Often, yes. 841 is commonly tied to failed delivery scenarios where the refund never successfully reached the taxpayer.

How is 841 different from 740?

Code 740 marks the undeliverable refund being returned, while Code 841 records the cancellation and crediting of that refund back to the account.

What steps typically come next for reissue?

Practitioners usually verify addresses and bank details, then look for a new 846 or 840 entry indicating reissue. If nothing appears, they may need to contact the IRS to request or confirm reissuance.
